moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4: So it starts off as a Nimzo-Indian https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nimzo-Indian_Defence
moves.4... c5: This is quite a reasonable move.
moves.5... d6: He seems to have a plan of putting his pawns on black squares.
moves.6. Nge2: And I have a plan to stop him doubling my c pawns.
moves.7. Bd2: Now I am thinking that maybe if he takes on c3 I can take back with my bishop and have a nice diagonal for it, after I move my d pawn.
moves.8. a3: This seems to me to be a natural move, but on the opening databases I use I can only find 0-0 here.
moves.8... Ba5: I was slightly surprised he didn't take - there would have been some logic in taking and then putting more pawns on black squares.
moves.10. d5: And notice how now we have a similar pawn formation to the Czech Benoni, just like the previous game.
moves.10... Ne7: The knight drops back. This position was seen in Jeremic, Veljko (2334) vs. Prelevic, Dusko (2385)		2001.03.13 when white continued with Rb1. That plan did cross my mind, but I chose something else - based on preventing his Bc8 finding any decent squares.
moves.11. Ng3: This is to stop his bishop - or his knight for that matter - coming to f5.
moves.11... Bg4: And the same move played in the previous game.
moves.12... Bd7: And the same retreat. Again, I think that black has just lost time. f2-f3 is a move I would quite like to make anyway.
moves.13. h3: I am planning f3-f4 but I didn't want a black piece returning to g4.
moves.13... a6: This maybe played more to deter Nc3-b5, as he never tries to play b7-b5.
moves.14. f4: So I continue with my plan.
moves.15... Qc8: This move got me thinking? Was he preparing to sacrifice on h3? Was he hoping to play a piece to f5?
moves.16. Qc2: This move seems to stop both. Bxh3 17. gxh3 Qxh3 18. Be1 and black doesn't have enough for the piece. But maybe f5 was a better move, constricting black more, and preventing his next move. It leaves e5 weak, but it is hard for black to exploit that weakness.
moves.16... Ng6: So he moves his knight to a better square.
moves.17. Rae1: This seemed to be a normal developing move.
moves.17... Bxh3: And now he plays it! Computer preferred b7-b5.
moves.18. Bxg6: Fritz says the best way to refute the bishop sacrifice was 18. f5!
moves.20. Nce4: I was scared stiff that he would win another pawn with Nxe4 21.	Nxe4	Qg4+ 22. Kf2 Rxf4+ 23. Bxf4	Qxf4+ 24. Ke2 Qg4+followed by taking my rook on e1 with his bishop on a5. I thought I couldn't play 22. Kh3 because of Rf5, but this is easily met by Ng3. However he didn't play that, he played this,-
moves.20... Bd8: I think this move is dire!
moves.21. Bc1: Played, to maintain my protection of f4 and also to free my queen for action along the 2nd rank, without blocking the e file.
moves.21... Ng4: He comes in, with potential mate on h2 if I am not careful.
moves.22. Qg2: This stops any of that nonsense.
moves.23. f5: This is a mistake. I should have just taken on d6. If he had taken on f5, I can't take back, because he takes back on f5 by his rook, and if I capture on f5 again, then my rook on e1 is taken by his queen. Luckily it doesn't really spoil anything.
moves.23... Bf6: Threatening a horrible check on d4.
moves.25... Ne5: He tries to shield it. OK stop and work out white's next.
moves.26. Re4: Did you get that? Black is in all sorts of trouble now.
moves.26... Ng4: The knight has to lamely retreat.
moves.27. Bxd6: And a pawn goes, attacking his rook.....
moves.27... Rfe8: ... which duly contests the e file.
moves.28. Rfe1: I could exchange and take on c5, but why give him any activity?
moves.29... Qg5: Moving his queen to somewhere more active.
moves.35. Qxe5: And now - with all sort of threats - he resigns. Many thanks for reading, please rate this annotation on the star system, and leave a comment or two. Merry Christmas, if I don't see you before then!

gameName: Telford A v Oswestry A, Shropshire League
players: Charles L Higgie (ECF177) vs. Richard Thompson (ECF154)
